title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, allowing qualified employers to not pay certain taxes on wages for services performed during that year. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" exempts qualified employers from certain taxes on wages for services performed by qualified individuals hired between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011. Qualified employers exclude the United States, States, local governments, or their instrumentalities. Qualified individuals must certify they have not worked more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting employment. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" exempts qualified employers from certain taxes on wages for services performed by qualified individuals hired between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011. Qualified individuals must certify they have not worked more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting employment. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to elect not to have certain tax exemptions apply to wages for qualified individuals hired between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011. This includes coordination with the Work Opportunity Credit and payroll tax forgiveness. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to elect not to have certain tax exemptions apply to wages for qualified individuals hired within a 1-year period. Amounts equal to the reduction in revenues will be appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendments made by this section shall have an effective date. The amendments made by the "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" aim to replicate transfers to the Trust Fund, with an effective date for wages paid after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The current year business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets specific criteria, including being employed for at least 52 consecutive weeks. The current year business credit will be increased by $1,000 for each retained worker who was employed for at least 52 consecutive weeks and whose wages for the last 26 weeks equaled at least 80 percent of the first 26 weeks.
